_accidents.CI_OtherType: Weld the ruptured hole on the pipe
cut and capped off the pipe on Compressor #12

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics' safety and environmental policies are administered by the General Manager and the Chief Engineer, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program. 



 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics facility is located at 625 W. Anaheim St. in Long Beach, California, which is located approximately 0.5 mile east of the Interstate 710 Freeway. The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of light commercial and industrial areas. The facility was constructed in the early 1920's.  



The facility is owned by All Fortune Group, LLC.  Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics is the tenant and will begin operating the refrigeration system in May 2012.



In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 15,108 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  Typical operating conditions range from 8.8" Hg on the low pressure side of the system to 180 psig on the high side.



The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant from liquid to gas and back again. The system, consisting of vessels, piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for ten refrigerated rooms, some of which are blast cells, and the heat exchanger.  System equipment is located inside the Engine Room, Outd

oor Engine Room, Refrigeration Rooms #2-#7, and on the roof.



The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Evaporative Condensers EC1 and EC2 to the High Pressure Receiver HPR.  The High Pressure Receiver HPR feeds high pressure liquid ammonia to the two Intercoolers VI1 and VI2 and the -40F Recirculator (HR3).  It also feeds liquid ammonia (liquid injection) to Booster Compressor BC1 and Compressors MC-2 and MC-11 for oil cooling.  It receives liquid transferred from the Liquid Transfer Vessel TR1.  



The Intercoolers VI1 & VI2 receive booster discharge from the Booster Compressors BC1 and FC-5.  The liquid makeup of the Intercoolers VI1 and VI2 through the High Pressure Receiver HPR1 is controlled by two float switches where one opens the solenoid valve and the other closes the solenoid valve.  The valve remains open until the liquid level in the Intercoolers VI1 & VI2 is satisfied.  The liquid flows through a hand expansion valve to reduce the pressure of the incoming liquid.  High pressure liquid is also routed through a coil that sits inside each Intercooler in a bath of liquid ammonia.  The liquid is thereby sub-cooled (such that the temperature is lower than the corresponding saturation pressure) and routed to the +20oF Recirculator HR2, -20F Recirculator VR1, and Surge Drums SD1, SD2, SD3, and SD4.   The resulting medium temperature vapor in the vessel rises to the top and is pulled off by Compressors YC-15 and MC-2.



The -40F Recirculator HR3 receives high pressure liquid from the High Pressure Receiver HPR1.  It pumps low temperature liquid to Blast Freezer Evaporators AU1, AU2, and AU3.  The     -20F Recirculator VR1, +20F Recirculator HR2, and Surge Drums SD1, SD2, SD3, and SD4 receive sub-cooled liquid from Intercoolers VI1 & VI2.   The -20F Recirculator VR1 pumps low temperature liquid ammonia to the coils in the Convertible Evaporators AU10 - AU-19 and Freezer Evaporators AU20 - AU-26.  The +20F Recirculator HR2 pu

mps medium temperature liquid ammonia to the coils in the Convertible Evaporators AU10 - AU-19 and Evaporator AU9.   Evaporators AU10 - AU19 are convertible type evaporators.  These evaporators can either receive low temperature liquid or medium temperature liquid depending on the facility's needs.  Surge Drums SD1, SD2, SD3, and SD4 feed liquid to Evaporators AU4 & AU5, AU6, AU7, and AU8, respectively.  As liquid flows through the evaporator coils, fans are used to transfer heat from the product in the room to the ammonia within the system.  This causes the ammonia to partially boil into vapor.  The resulting 'wet return' (liquid/vapor mixture) from Evaporators AU1, AU2, and AU3 is returned to the -40F Recirculator HR3.  Evaporator AU9 returns medium temperature 'wet suction' to the +20F Recirculator HR2.  Evaporators AU20 - AU26 return low temperature 'wet suction' to the -20F Recirculator VR1.  Evaporators AU10 - AU19 return low temperature 'wet suction' and medium temperature 'wet suction' to the -20F Recirculator VR1 and +20F Recirculator HR2, respectively, depending on facility needs.  Evaporators AU4 & AU5, AU6, AU7, and AU8 return 'wet suction' to Surge Drums SD1, SD2, SD3, and SD4, respectively.  Dry low temperature suction from Surge Drums SD1, SD2, SD3, and SD4 is sent to the Suction Accumulator SA1.



At the -20F Recirculator HR2 and +20F Recirculator VR1, liquid drops to the bottom of the vessel and vapor rises to the top and is pulled off by Compressor MC-11 and Compressors YC-15 and MC-2, respectively.  At the -40F Recirculator HR3, liquid drops to the bottom of the vessel and vapor rises to the top and is discharged to the Suction Accumulator SA1.  Excess liquid from the -20F Recirculator VR1, +20F Recirculator, and -40F Recirculator HR3 is transferred to the Suction Accumulator SA1.



At the Suction Accumulator SA1, liquid drops to the bottom of the vessel and is drained to the Liquid Transfer Vessel TR1.  The gas in the Suction Accumulator SA1 ri

ses to the top and is pulled off by the Booster Compressors BC1 and FC-5.



Hot gas from Compressors YC-15, MC-11, and MC-2 is used to pressurize the Liquid Transfer Vessel TR1 and transfer excess liquid to the High Pressure Receiver HPR1 to be reused in the refrigeration process.  



Booster Compressors FC-5 and BC1 draw low temperature suction from the Suction Accumulator SA1.  Compressors YC-15 and MC-2 draw medium temperature suction from the Intercoolers VI1 and VI2 and the +20F Recirculator HR2.  Compressor MC-11 draws low temperature suction from the -20F Recirculator VR1.  The compressors raise the pressure of the gas.  Booster Compressors FC-5 and BC1 discharge booster discharge to Intercoolers VI1 and VI2 while Compressors YC-15, MC-11, and MC-2 discharges hot gas to the Underfloor Heat Exchanger HX1 to heat the concrete floor in the freezer room to prevent cracking; the Hot Water Defrost Heat Exchanger HX2 to heat up the water for water defrost of Evaporators AU3 to AU8; the Liquid Transfer Vessel TR1 to transfer liquid to the High Pressure Receiver HPR1; and Evaporators AU1, AU2, AU3, and AU9 - AU26 for hot gas defrost.  Compressors FC-5 and YC-15 serve as back-up compressors.



The Underfloor Heat Exchanger HX1 is a shell and tube heat exchanger which is designed to be used in a separate, closed loop system for under floor heating.  The Underfloor Heat Exchanger HX1 receives hot gas discharge from Compressors YC-15, MC-11, and MC-2.  As the high temperature ammonia vapor passes through the heat exchanger unit, it is partially condensed as the glycol absorbs heat from the ammonia.  The resulting hot gas discharge (liquid/vapor mixture) flows to the Evaporative Condensers EC1 & EC2,



The Hot Water Defrost Heat Exchanger HX2 is a plate and frame heat exchanger.   Hot gas discharge from Compressors YC-15, MC-11, and MC-2 flows on one side of the plate while water flows on the other side of the plates.  High temperature ammonia vapor partially condenses

as the water absorbs heat from the ammonia.  The resulting hot gas discharge (liquid/vapor mixture) flows to the Evaporative Condensers EC1 and EC2.  



At the Evaporative Condensers EC1 and EC2, air (fans) and water (pumps) are used to condense the hot gas discharge into high pressure liquid, which then drains to the High Pressure Receiver HPR to begin the refrigeration cycle again.  The system is also equipped with an Automatic Purger that removes non-condensables, i.e. air, from the system.



The ASME vessels and compressor oil separators are equipped with pressure relief valves which are set to actuate at 250 psig or 300 psig on the compressors , the High Pressure Receiver HPR1, the Shell and Tube Heat Exchanger HX1, and the Liquid Transfer Vessel TR1; and 150 psig on the following ammonia process equipment:  Intercoolers VI1 & VI2, -20F Recirculator VR1, +20F Recirculator HR2, -40F Recirculator HR3 and associated oil pot OP1, Surge Drums SD1 - SD4, and Suction Accumulator SA1.  All of the relief valves are tied into a common relief header that vent to the Ammonia Diffusion Tank except for the relief valves on the compressors which vents internally and the Surge Drums SD1-SD4 which vent to the atmosphere.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA), Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Section 5189 of Title 8, CCR), the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP), and the California Emergency Management Agency (Cal EMA) California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.



Administrative Measures:  The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:



- IIAR Bulletin 107, "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie ins "

- IIAR Bul

letin 109, "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System"

- IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems"

- IIAR, "A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



The Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program, CalOSHA PSM Program, and EPA RMP Program.  It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  Pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels protect the equipment from overpressurization.



 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



An investigation into the facility's accident history over the past five years (August 2006 to August 2011) revealed that there have been four ammonia releases that meet the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  All four releases warranted an internal incident investigation.  One release resulted in an injury.  These four release incidents occurred at the time International Juice Concentrates, Inc. was leasing the property.  Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics is the new tenant since August 2011. The property damage amount for the three incidents dated July 8, 2008, June 17, 2009, and July 4, 2009 were unknown, therefore reported as $0.  Th

e four incidents are detailed below:



July 2008 Incident:

On July 8, 2008 at 9:30 AM, ammonia vapor was released from an evaporator coil in Room #8.  An employee was chipping ice off of the evaporator and accidentally hit a small pipe causing the line to rupture and spray vapor on the left side of his face and his eyes.  The employee was taken to the hospital for treatment.  The Long Beach Fire Department was notified.  All employees were quarantined from the leak.  Once safe, the facility called the refrigeration contractor, Mericle Mechanical, to weld the ruptured hole on the pipe.  The Long Beach Health Department was also onsite to monitor the situation.  After the leak was stopped, the Heath Department representative declared the room safe enough to enter.  Once the ammonia threshold was low enough for safe entrance, employees were allowed back into the facility.  The Long Beach Fire Department and the Hazmat Team were on site for approximately six and a half hours.  The Long Beach Health Department representative came back the next day and declared that it was safe for employees to return to work.



June 2009 Incident:

At 11:30 PM on June 17, 2009, the Operations Manager smelled ammonia in his office.  The Operations Manager reported this to the President and both performed a walk through of the facility to investigate where the ammonia smell was coming from.  They identified that the smell was from the Engine Room.  The Long Beach Fire Department was called and arrived on scene.  The facility also alerted the Chief Engineer and the Maintenance Manager who arrived on site shortly after.  The Hazmat Team also arrived and the building was shut off.  All streets surrounding the facility were closed off from public access.  The Hazmat Team shut off the "King" valve to stop all liquid supply to the Plant.  The Chief Engineer was then allowed to enter the building to assist the Hazmat team with the investigation.  They then identified that the ammonia leak was

from the Compressor #12.  The thread of the ?" pipe cap as well as the shaft seal were leaking.  The refrigeration contractor, TDI Refrigeration, assisted the Chief Engineer to remove the ?" pipe cap and replaced it with a 3/8" pipe plug and stopped the leak.  Once the ammonia threshold reached a nonexistent level, the Health Department declared the building and surrounding property safe, and operations resumed as usual.  TDI Refrigeration and the Chief Engineer returned the next day for a follow up.  It is estimated that approximately 80 pounds of ammonia was released.  The Facility Manager met with the City of Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services as well as an OSHA representative on June 18, 2009 to complete the necessary follow-up and address inquiries on incident.  The president completed a written report to the National Response Center and the California Office of Emergency Services. 



July 2009 Incident:

At 3:20 PM on July 4, 2009, an ammonia leak reoccurred on Compressor #12.  The Long Beach Fire Department was called onsite.  They blocked off the streets and a perimeter was set up.  The Long Beach Fire Department estimated 20 pounds of ammonia was released.  The refrigeration contractor, TDI Refrigeration, and the Maintenance Operator were allowed to enter the Engine Room and shut down the compressor.  The Facilities Manager then notified the National Response Center and the California Office of Emergency Services.  The refrigeration contractor cut an capped off the pipe on Compressor #12.



August 2009 Incident:

At 7:15 PM on August 27, 2009 there was an ammonia leak from the Compressor #12 shaft seal and packing.  The Fish Processing Supervisor smelled ammonia and alerted the Vice President who then informed the President.  The Long Beach Fire Department was notified and came onsite.  The Human Resources & Facility Manager, the Chief Engineer, and the Engineering Assistant were called and arrived on site shortly after.  All personnel eva

cuated the building with the assistance from the Long Beach Fire Department and the President.  The Human Resource & Facility Manager and the Maintenance Operator assisted the Long Beach Fire Department to find the source of the leak.  The Maintenance Operator shut down the system.  Once the ammonia concentration dropped to a non-detectable level, at approximately 8:00 PM, the fire department reported the building to be safe for re-entry and work. An incident investigation report was prepared.  The incident was reported to the Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services and the Long Beach Fire Prevention Bureau.  The Vice President then contacted the State of California Office of Emergency Services and filed a report on the ammonia release incident.  



The Chief Engineer determined that the Compressor #11 shut down causing a high pressure on the Low Stage Compressors #1 and #14.  Compressor #1 shut off when the high pressure cutoff setting was reached.  The high pressure cutout for Compressor #14 was set too high, and the pressure switch did not shut off the compressor.  This caused the pressure to be higher than normal.  As a result, approximately 10 pounds of ammonia was released through Compressor #12.  There were no injuries that resulted from this incident.  As a resolution, the seal on Compressor #12 was tightened to reduce pressure in the system and to stop ammonia from leaking.  The Chief Engineer recommended to lower the pressure cutoff setting on Compressor #14 to 45 psig to prevent high pressure buildup when it is running and to shut down for any abnormal condition.  The Mycom technician was called to assess Compressor #11 and assure it is safe for use.  

 

 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  



- save lives;

- minimize and avoid injuries;

- protect the environment; and

- minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the resp

onse organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.  

  

Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger and the Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics Chief Engineer/General Manager/ designee.  The Chief Engineer/General Manager/designee will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem. Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) performed on August 31, 2011 and on October 14, 2011 generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics facility located in Long Beach, California.  The mitigation measures include installing an alarm system that triggers an audible alarm throughout the facility, specifically in the refrigeration spaces and the Outdoor Engine Room.   Other mitigation measures included additional training, key maintenance related tests/inspection, and develop an emergency action policies and procedures.  The Long Beach Cold Storage & Logistics safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee i

nvolvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
